ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained an understanding of current methods in cog sci and became a better scientific writer. Seeing how easy it is to make and run studies with prolific was a high point. I also feel like I have a better understanding of the brain from a physical POV due to the first third of the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - the prof and TF both are wonderful educators that care about the class and are genuinely talented teachers. The material is interesting and the class examples are creative and often fun. We need more classes like this at Yale.

Weaknesses - so early on a Friday and mainly composed of seniors (a population that is very likely to be out late on Thursday nights due to society)
Learned a lot, but not a stressful class. Pretty chill.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The only reason a neuroscience major should graduate without having taken this class is because they didn't make the lottery to get in. It respects your time while still be informative and interesting. I can't recommend Prof Lazzaro enough.
Yes, you learn a good amount, and it's not terribly difficult.
